spanishExample: ¡Ah! En verdad no hablamos.
englishTranslation: Ah! We actually don’t speak.
vocabIncluded: hablamos: speak, we speak (Hablar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Ay!... ¡No pasa nada! Estoy bien.
englishTranslation: Ouch!... No worries! I’m fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things

spanishExample: ¡Basta! ¡Por favor hable con ellos!
englishTranslation: Enough! Please talk(formal) to them!

spanishExample: ¡Claro! Sí, ella pasa demasiado tiempo aquí.
englishTranslation: Of course! Yes, she spends too much time here.
vocabIncluded: pasa: passes, he/she/it passes (Pasar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Dale! Él no me dio su número.
englishTranslation: Go ahead! He didn’t give me his number.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: ¡Hey! Tengo un par de cosas para ti.
englishTranslation: Hey! I have a couple of things for you.

spanishExample: ¡No hables con él o no pasará su clase!
englishTranslation: Don’t talk to him or he won’t pass his class!
vocabIncluded: pasará: will pass, he/she/it will pass (Pasar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Pasa y habla con nosotros!
englishTranslation: Come in and talk with us!

spanishExample: ¡Pase! Vamos a pasarlo bien.
englishTranslation: (formal) Come in! We’re going to have a good time.
vocabIncluded: pasarlo bien: "to have a good time" (idiom)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡Por fin! No te habíamos visto.
englishTranslation: Finally! We hadn’t seen you.
vocabIncluded: habíamos: "had", "we had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¿Cuántos libros tienes ahí?
englishTranslation: How many books do you have there?
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: ¿Pasas mucho tiempo ahí?
englishTranslation: Do you spend much time there?
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
pasas: pass, you pass (Pasar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Bueno, pon tus cosas aquí.
englishTranslation: All right, put your things here.

spanishExample: Cuanto más hablamos, más tiempo pasamos aquí.
englishTranslation: The more we talk, the more time we spend here.
vocabIncluded: hablamos: speak, we speak (Hablar, present, 1st person plural)
pasamos: pass, we pass (Pasar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Eh, tiene unas cuantas cosas.
englishTranslation: Hmm, he has a small number of things.

spanishExample: Él quiere que hablemos cuanto queramos.
englishTranslation: He wants us to talk as much as we want.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cuanto used with a subjunctive to mean "as much as", as in “cuanto quiera” (pronoun)
hablemos: speak, we speak (Hablar, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ella hablará con ellos y ellos hablarán con nosotros.
englishTranslation: She will talk to them and they will talk to us.
vocabIncluded: hablará: will speak, he/she/it will speak (Hablar, future, 3rd person)
hablarán: will speak, they will speak (Hablar, future, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Ella quiere hablar de lo que pasó.
englishTranslation: She wants to talk about what happened.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: En cuanto a eso, yo no hablaba de la muerte.
englishTranslation: Regarding that, I wasn’t talking about death.
vocabIncluded: de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablaba: was speaking, I was speaking (Hablar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: En fin, no pasa nada, siempre hablamos.
englishTranslation: Anyway, it’s fine, we always talk.
vocabIncluded: en fin: “anyway” / “in a nutshell” / “all in all” (idiom)
hablamos: speak, we speak (Hablar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ese es un buen punto, quieres que ella vaya a la fiesta.
englishTranslation: That’s a good point, you want her to go to the party.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Hablaba con él, entonces le diré adiós.
englishTranslation: I was talking to him, so I’ll tell him goodbye.
vocabIncluded: diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)
hablaba: was speaking, I was speaking (Hablar, imperfect, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Hablarás con ellos cuando yo pase tiempo ahí.
englishTranslation: You’ll talk to them when I spend time there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
hablarás: will speak, you will speak (Hablar, future, 2nd person)
pase: pass, I pass (Pasar, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Hablaré con usted del final del libro.
englishTranslation: (Formal) I’ll talk to you about the ending of the book.
vocabIncluded: del: "of the" before a masculine noun
hablaré: will speak, I will speak (Hablar, future, 1st person)
usted: formal "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: Hablaremos mañana en cuanto a tu problema.
englishTranslation: We’ll talk tomorrow regarding your problem.
vocabIncluded: hablaremos: will speak, we will speak (Hablar, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Hablaron ayer y sus cosas todavía están aquí.
englishTranslation: They talked yesterday and their things are still here.
vocabIncluded: hablaron: spoke, they spoke (Hablar, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Hablé con él y ahora estamos pasando tiempo en casa.
englishTranslation: I talked to him and now we’re spending time at home.
vocabIncluded: hablé: spoke, I spoke (Hablar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Hemos hablado mucho, ¡nos vemos!
englishTranslation: We have talked a lot, see ya!
vocabIncluded: hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No quiero que hable con su amigo.
englishTranslation: I don’t want him to talk to his friend.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hable: speak, he/she/it speak (Hablar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No quiero que hables porque estamos en el medio de un problema.
englishTranslation: I don’t want you to talk because we’re in the middle of a problem.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hables: speak, you speak (Hablar, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Oh, cuanto menos vayas, menos tendrás que hacer.
englishTranslation: Oh, the less you go, the less you will have to do.
vocabIncluded: no vayas: "don't go", imperative (Ir, imperative, 2nd person)
tendrás: "will have", "you will have" (Tener, future, 2nd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Pasan cuanto tiempo quieren con sus libros.
englishTranslation: They spend as much time as they want with their books.
vocabIncluded: cuanto: "as much" or "as much as" (indefinite adjective)
pasan: pass, they pass (Pasar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Pasé la clase y quiero que ella la pase también.
englishTranslation: I passed the class and I want her to pass it as well.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pase: pass, he/she/it pass (Pasar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
pasé: passed, I passed (Pasar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Perdón, pero estamos hablando ya mismo.
englishTranslation: Sorry, but we’re talking right now.

spanishExample: Pues, ella no quiso pasarlo.
englishTranslation: Well, she didn’t mean to pass it.
vocabIncluded: pasarlo: to pass it (Pasar infinitive contraction)

spanishExample: Quieren que lo pasemos bien.
englishTranslation: They want us to have a good time.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pasarlo bien: "to have a good time" (idiom)
pasemos: pass, we pass (Pasar, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Sabía que no fue el fin.
englishTranslation: He knew that it wasn’t the end.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Será el fin para ella cuando yo hable.
englishTranslation: It’ll be the end for her when I speak.
vocabIncluded: hable: speak, I speak (Hablar, subjunctive, 1st person)
será: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Ser, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si hablas, serás como ella, ya que ella también habló.
englishTranslation: If you speak, you’ll be like her, since she also spoke.
vocabIncluded: hablas: speak, you speak (Hablar, present, 2nd person)
habló: spoke, he/she/it spoke (Hablar, preterite, 3rd person)
serás: "will be", "you will be" (Ser, future, 2nd person)
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Si yo hablo, no puedes hablar.
englishTranslation: If I talk, you can’t talk.
vocabIncluded: hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
hablo: speak, I speak (Hablar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Siempre hablan, pero al final no hacen nada.
englishTranslation: They always talk, but in the end they don’t do anything.
vocabIncluded: hablan: speak, they speak (Hablar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Tengo que pasar la clase o no puedo ir.
englishTranslation: I have to pass the class or I can’t go.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
